content.div:
How do you play an instrument at 65 km/h? That's the sort of question only OK GO would ask themselves. (OK...maybe these guys, too.)

And after watching the pop-rockers' new video for "Needing/Getting" they clearly got their answer.

That answer? You do it by designing an elaborate race track -- one outfitted with 288 guitars, 55 pianos, 1,157 "homemade instruments." Then, if you're OK GO singer Damian Kulash, you take lessons from a pro Hollywood stunt driver, find some car company to sponsor you -- and drive a new, zazzed-out vehicle through the whole set-up.

The outcome? The sound of "Needing/Getting" -- and a music video that manages to out-quirk any Rube Goldberg machine, puppy parade or treadmill-based routine the band has ever engineered. As OK GO writes on their website, it's the "most amazingly bizarre video" they've ever created -- and we've posted it below.

The clip debuted Super Bowl Sunday, and considering it's brought to you by a certain car manufacturer of America (Chevy), you could say it qualifies as one of the year's splashiest Super Bowl ads. (As Kulash told MTV News, the video's budget was in the six figures.)

More of those Super Bowl ads can be found here, but back to the video. Kulash told MTV News a little about what goes into turning a Chevy into a four-doored band.

"It consumed my whole life for four months," the singer told MTV, explaining that the video was recorded in segments which were pieced together to form the full song. (They've done a single-take video already, anyway. Nobody likes to repeat themselves.)

"We were out in the desert until midnight every day. I don't even remember having a life outside of that," he continues. "Everyone who came out to help for a day or two was like 'I can't believe you built such an insane wonderland in the desert."

OK Go's music video "All Is Not Lost" is nominated for a Grammy this year.

Watch the video for "Needing/Getting" below:

leahc@dose.ca
